newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan firm to take part in Philippine IPP project.
newsitem.headline: Japan firm to take part in Philippine IPP project.

text.p: Japan's Electric Power Development Co Ltd will take part in a geothermal power plant project on Leyte island in the Philippines, by investing capital in the main operator, a company official said on Friday.
It will be the first time for a Japanese power company to take part in an overseas independent power provider (IPP) project, he said.

Semi-governmental Electric Power Development Co said in a statement that it has agreed to take a 10 percent stake in Ormat Leyte, the project's main operator. Ormat Leyte is a local subsidiary of U.S. company Ormat Inc.
The capital participation of about $1.67 million will be made by the Japanese company's subsidiary, EPDC International.
Japanese trading company Itochu Corp has also agreed to take a 10 percent stake in Ormat Leyte, the statement said.
The remaining 80 percent of Ormat Leyte's total capital of $16.7 million will be provided by the U.S. parent company.
Ormat Leyte has won PNOC-Energy Development Corp's tender to construct a 49,000-kilowatt geothermal power plant on Leyte island, about 600 km south of Manila.
PNOC-Energy is a subsidiary of state-run Philippine National Oil Co.
The total cost of the project, which started construction in February, is estimated at about $670,000.
The plant is due to be completed in October.
